newsitem.title: GERMANY: FOCUS - EMU criterion need not be exactly met - Krupp.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - EMU criterion need not be exactly met - Krupp.

text.p: Nations seeking to qualify for European monetary union do not need to hit the EMU debt criterion exactly to qualify, Bundesbank council member Hans-Juergen Krupp said on Monday.

Speaking at a savings bank meeting in Hamburg, the president of the Hamburg, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern and Schleswig-Holstein central bank said there would be room to manoeuvre, particularly in the area of public debt.
"The 60-percent debt-to-GDP ratio is barely justifiable on grounds of economic theory, as (the debt) is above all a product of historical developments," said Krupp.
Krupp went on to say: "As the example of Belgium shows, extremely high levels of Belgian government debt do not work against its close relationship with the deutschemark and low rates of inflation."
Belgium, which has debt of around 130 percent of its total economic output, has maintained a stable currency for the last few years and has its interest rates closely pegged to those of the mark.

The Maastricht criteria were "not so flexible that every EU country could take advantage of them," and it was foreseeable "that not all EU countries would take part in monetary union in 1999," Krupp said.
But he made clear that there could be no flexibility on the other criteria laid down in the Maastricht Treaty.
Sticking to the stability criteria regarding inflation, exchange rates and long-term interest rates was unavoidable and there could be no room for interpretation on these matters, Krupp said.
Krupp said after the meeting that he thought there was no doubt that Germany would fulfil the criteria necessary for monetary union. He did express reservations about Britain, however.
"It is regrettable that Britain and Sweden have decided to forego obligatory membership of monetary union," he said.

"In the case of Britain this casts further doubt on the appropriateness of that country being within Europe. As it is legally contentious whether or not a country can be forced to take part in monetary union under EU rules, it will have to follow of its own free will," said Krupp.
Krupp said he also thought that if Germany did not come in under the three percent criteria, it could have negative effects on the currency.
He said he expected the single currency to have only narrow fluctuations against the dollar and the yen.
